you need to modify your host file to keep app from phoning home. this is what is explained in read me.
Can someone explain how to stop it calling home everytime? I cannot see this in the instructions ? Instructions call for this folder "sudo pico / private / etc / hosts " I cannot find this folder.

I haven't downloaded it yet but modifying the hosts file to prevent calling home is basically this:

sudo nano /etc/hosts

In this file you'll see a few lines such as 

127.0.0.1 localhost
::1 localhost

These lines tell your computer to reroute all requests to localhost to 127.0.0.1 or ::1. You need to add a line that routes all requests to adobe.com to another address that isn't adobe.com. 

Keep in mind that hosts file operates under an exact match setting. In other words, adobe.com is not http://www.adobe.com nor is it https://www.adobe.com. It either matches exactly or it doesn't match at all. You need to include all cases that the program you want to block might try.

Gracias al aporte de Josvila he instalado la suite, pero como la mayoría de usuarios de Mac hemos escogido este sistema por la sencillez de su funcionamiento y no queremos entrar en sus interioridades, he probado otra alternativa más sencilla que la que indicada y me ha funcionado perfectamente.
Simplemente una vez que el archivo "ADBESTAMCS4_LS4.dmg" que hemos descargado este en el escritorio le damos doble clik y que se abra en el escritorio, abrimos la carpeta y encontraremos un icono de "SETUP" le damos a este y se abrirá el instalador, (paciencia...)una vez abierto, aquí colocaremos el serial que está en la carpeta inicial del torrent bajado, tiene que empezar por 1325-....-....- lo insertamos y empezara la instalación. más paciencia.
CONSEJO: No es necesario instalar toda la suite ya que es muy ámplia y seguramente no necesitaremos todas las aplicaciones, podemos instalarlas más adelante.
MUY IMPORTANTE: Una vez este la carpeta bajada en el escritorio y antes de instalar nada, desconectarse de INTERNET, instalar las app que necesitemos, abrirlas, probarlas, y después de esto reiniciamos, ya podemos conectarnos a INTERNET.
No es necesario desinstalar las versiones anteriores, pero una vez comprobado que funcionan las nuevas se pueden desisntalar, más que todo por el espacio en disco y que al clicar un archivo se abra una u otra.

ok that's my question Mathfreak.
Where is this folder "sudo nano /etc/hosts" on a mac?
I cannot find it

It's not a folder. hosts is a file located in the folder /etc

Just go into Terminal (it's located in the Utilities folder). Terminal is a black screen that looks like MSDOS in windows. If you don't see this screen then you are in the wrong place. 

Once you find this screen, type the command:

sudo nano /etc/hosts

This will ask for your account password. Enter it in and press enter. Please note that with UNIX, passwords aren't visible so it will seem like your computer has been frozen. Don't worry. Just enter it and press enter. This will open up your hosts file for editing.

If you're still having issues, please tell me your version of Mac OS X that you're running. You can find that out by clicking the Apple icon in your menu bar and then clicking "About this Mac".

Hope this helped.

To anyone having the problem with "Licensing for this product has expired", the following worked for me. You must be logged in as the administrator on your mac. Also, obviously, you should only do it if you own and have paid for a legitimate copy of the product (clears throat)

OK! Install Adobe but don't launch it. (If you already have it installed, use AppZapper to completely delete it.) Now turn off your AirPort to stop the computer connecting to the internet.

Launch Terminal from Applications / Utilities. 

Type sudo pico /etc/hosts

You will be prompted to enter your password. Nothing will appear onscreen while you do, but enter it anyway and press enter.

A very lo-tech-looking text editor will flash up, with one or two entries beginning 127.0.0.1 in it. Use the arrow keys to navigate to the beginning of these entries. You need to get the following entries in there: use the TAB key to insert a linebreak.

127.0.0.1 activate.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 practivate.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 ereg.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 activate.wip3.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 wip3.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 3dns-3.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 3dns-2.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 adobe-dns.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 adobe-dns-2.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 adobe-dns-3.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 ereg.wip3.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 activate-sea.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 wwis-dubc1-vip60.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 activate-sjc0.adobe.com

When you're done, press CTRL-X to exit. It will ask you if you want to save changes. Hit Y. You have now edited the hosts file to stop Adobe phoning home. Don't stop! There is more.

[Sidenote: the bit above becomes very much easier if you can be bothered to get hold of BBEdit, install its command-line tools and then open terminal and type bbedit /etc/hosts. Then copy/paste the list and save.]

NOW: to get rid of the "Registration has expired" thing, do the following:

Quit all Adobe programs and delete the following file:

/Library/Application Support/Adobe/Adobe PCD/cache/cache.db

NB that this should be in the Library folder of your root directory, ie Mac HD, or whatever you've called your hard disk. There's another Library folder under your username under Users, but it doesn't have the Adobe PCD folder in so it isn't the one we want.

Now launch your Adobe app and enter one of the following serials. Make a note which one you used in case you want to install and activate any others. Don't connect to the net just yet.

1325-0321-2015-7091-9681-7717
1325-0181-3738-0615-5739-9898
1325-0084-0806-2185-0302-7354
1325-0112-3840-5467-8974-0282
1325-0248-9800-0187-7623-7106
1325-0412-0855-1375-6305-7806
1325-0581-1108-1105-1944-2760
1325-0213-2599-6032-5159-4780
1325-0882-6599-8787-6439-6137
1325-0261-4811-3496-3493-1549

A tick will appear beside it when you have it right. Hit continue. I don't know if it's safe to run the Updater that may appear, so I have avoided doing so. Quit Photoshop and restart to check everything is OK, then you should be able to reconnect to the net and breathe a sigh of relief. You're done.

Apologies if some of these steps are repeats or redundant. Thanks should go to the various sites all over the net that came up with the separate bits of this explanation: all I have done is put them together. Good luck!

=== HOW TO INSTALL CS4 ===
8.5GB CS4 MASTER Version:


1. If you have CS3, run the CS3 clean script: http://www.adobe.com/support/contact/cs3clean.html
2. Change the Date to something like 18th December 2008
3. Block adobe's activation in etc/hosts - by bsodmike (see below)
3.1. Test if it really blocked: on the Terminal, run "ping activate.wip3.adobe.com" it must show 127.0.0.1 instead of 192.150.14.69
3.2. I turned my internet off, just in case...
4. Install CS4 (open the .dmg and run the setup)
4.1. Use capslockasdf serial's (see below)
4.2. On the Registration step, choose: Register Later (just never register)
5. Update your Calendar to today (item 2)
5.1. Reconnect your internet (item 3.2)
6. Run the Updater: /Applications/Utilities/Adobe Utilities/Adobe Updater6/Adobe Updater.app
6.1. It updated fine to Photoshop 11.0.1 and InDesign 6.0.1 on Apr/13/09
6.2. On the Updater Preferences, i've disabled the automatic updates, just in case...

===============================================================
============== item 3 - activation server blocks ==============
===============================================================	

Here are the steps:

A. open the terminal.app
B. type "sudo -s" [without quotes]
C. if asked, type your root password and hit enter
D. type "pico /etc/hosts" [without quotes]
E. copy the list you find in the post of bsodmike (below) and past in your terminal (at the end of this hosts file)
F. ctrl+x to exit, y to save and enter to confirm the same name and modify your hosts file.

bsodmike's list:


# Block Adobe Activation
127.0.0.1 activate.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 practivate.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 ereg.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 activate.wip3.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 wip3.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 3dns-3.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 3dns-2.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 adobe-dns.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 adobe-dns-2.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 adobe-dns-3.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 ereg.wip3.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 activate-sea.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 wwis-dubc1-vip60.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 activate-sjc0.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 hl2rcv.adobe.com


And an example, this is what my hosts file looks like. 
Yours should be similar, what is important is how I pasted the above bit into it!:

##
# Host Database
#
# localhost is used to configure the loopback interface
# when the system is booting. Do not change this entry.
##
127.0.0.1 localhost
255.255.255.255 broadcasthost
::1 localhost
fe80::1%lo0 localhost

# Block Adobe Activation
127.0.0.1 activate.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 practivate.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 ereg.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 activate.wip3.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 wip3.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 3dns-3.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 3dns-2.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 adobe-dns.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 adobe-dns-2.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 adobe-dns-3.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 ereg.wip3.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 activate-sea.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 wwis-dubc1-vip60.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 activate-sjc0.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 hl2rcv.adobe.com



===============================================================
============== item 4.1. - serials =============
===============================================================

>> This is if you already had CS4 working  Deactivate > check the Remove key option > hit OK to confirm it. The program closes immediately afterwards
4. change the date back to the proper date
5. find that /Library/Application Support/Adobe/Adobe PCD/cache/cache.db
( I could have sworn the Adobe PCD folder and the cache file wasn't there before I deactivated it, but now it's there)
6. delete that shit -- it'll ask for your admin password
7. start up any cs4 program again (i used dreamweaver)
8. punch in a new serial

6. Open Terminal (found in Applications/Utilities/). In the terminal window, paste in:

sudo /Applications/TextEdit.app/Contents/MacOS/TextEdit /etc/hosts

Hit return and type in your admin password.

A file will automatically open in TextEdit. In TextEdit, at the bottom of the document, hit return and paste in the following:

127.0.0.1 activate.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 practivate.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 ereg.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 activate.wip3.adobe.com

127.0.0.1 activate-sea.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 wwis-dubc1-vip60.adobe.com
127.0.0.1 activate-sjc0.adobe.com

Save the file. Do NOT do a 'Save As'. Close the file.

!!!! This is not a mistake in step 4 you were supposed to undo these changes if you had edited the file before and had CS4 that suddenly stopped working.

7. In a new terminal window, paste in:

sudo dscacheutil -flushcache

Hit return and type in your admin password [if asked again].

8. Launch any CS4 app and enter the serial:

1325-0505-2949-5043-2724-3432

to clean:

CS4: http://www.adobe.com/support/contact/cs4clean.html


AND THIS:

open a terminal, and become super user ( namely root) using the command 
"sudo -s" (without quotes) and when it asks, give your password. and delete the file 
"cd /Library/Application\ Support/Adobe/Adobe\ PCD/cache/cache.db" using the command "rm" ex. 
"rm cd /Library/Application\ Support/Adobe/Adobe\ PCD/cache/cache.db"
when you reopen any adobe mc app. it will ask you a serial, and you know the rest of the story.  good luck.
